answer_html: \(\displaystyle (x^{2}-4)^{2} = 0\) and so \(\displaystyle 0 = (x-2)(x+2)\) giving solutions \(\displaystyle x = \pm 2\).

sols_html:
Setting the numerator and the denominator of the first derivative to 0 gives

\(\displaystyle -8x = 0\) and so \(\displaystyle x=0\)

\(\displaystyle (x^{2}-4)^{2} = 0\) and so \(\displaystyle 0 = x^{2}-4 = (x-2)(x+2)\) giving solutions \(\displaystyle x = \pm 2\).

statement_html:
Consider the function

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = \frac{x^{2}}{x^{2} - 4}.\end{aligned}\]

Its first and second derivatives are given by

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x) = -\frac{8x}{(x^{2} - 4)^{2}}, \quad f''(x) = \frac{8(3x^{2} + 4)}{(x^{2} - 4)^{3}}\end{aligned}\]

(a) Find all \(x\) such that \(f'(x) = 0\) or \(f'(x)\) does not exist.
